text:
Q: How exactly does SSR work when it comes to lazy loaded components? A:

SSR with lazy components doesn't pre-render the lazy component on the server. Instead:

1. **With `ssr: true`** → Server renders placeholder/loading state. Browser receives HTML, then loads the component chunk when needed.

2. **With `ssr: false`** → Component skipped entirely on server. Only rendered in browser after JS loads.

**The point of SSR with lazy-loading:**

- Faster initial page load (server sends HTML immediately)

- Better SEO for the main content

- Lazy components still load on-demand, saving bandwidth

So you get the best of both: instant page delivery + code-splitting benefits. It's not "render everything server-side" – it's "render what matters first, load the rest later."

**Your confusion:** You expected SSR to defeat the purpose of lazy-loading. It doesn't – they work together. SSR handles critical content, lazy-loading handles optional/below-fold stuff.

Q: Populate Field Description, Status Bar Text, Control Tip Text in MS Access from a table A:

First-off: exactly what version of MS Access are you using? (Access 2016? 2013? 2007? 2003?) and what kind of database files are you using (.mdb, .accdb, any Linked Servers?).

Please share the CREATE TABLE definition of your Data Dictionary table and some excerpted rows - so we can properly understand the situation. Are you using a single table (which, presumably, contains details for columns - but not for other types of objects, like tables and views/queries?).

Speaking of Data-Dictionaries, are you familiar with MSysObjects and other Access built-ins?

Also, when you say "status bar" - are you referring to Access' main UI's status-bar? - or the status-bar in your own Access Forms that live inside your database? Or something else?

Q: how to enforce not-None for Optional arguments to Pydantic models A: 
    def get_foo(self) -> str:
        assert instanceof(self.foo, str)
        return self.foo

That will type check just fine.

You could alternatively return f"{self.foo}", if you're willing to perhaps return a nonsensical "None" string.

In some situations I would just assert self.foo, if I know that a valid .foo won't be the empty string.

(PEP 8 asks that instead of getfoo() you prefer snake-case names like get_foo().)

Q: websocket.close() being called but not closing, not sending close frame A:

After working on this all day, I have finally found the problem...

As mentioned above, I was doing this (simplified):

ws.send('hey, client is logging off now');

ws.close();

Based on how the three different browsers executed this code, it appears that sending a message through a WebSocket then immediately closing the WebSocket will cause the 'close' opcode (0x8) not to be sent to the server. This seems like a bug or poor implementation on the part of the browsers but I decided to make a workaround...

  • I removed the ws.close() call right after the final ws.send() call.

  • I then wrote a handler in my PHP WebSocket server which recognized the "hey, client is logging off now" message, then sent a message back to the client saying (simplified) "go ahead and close the connection"

  • I added a handler to my web client that recognized the server's "go ahead and close the connection" message, which then executed ws.close()

  • The browser's WebSocket implementation then properly sent the close opcode 0x8 to the server and the server then sent the close frame back

  • The WebSocket closed properly and cleanly with a 1000 code and no errors

In addition, just as @Olivier mentioned, the close frame never shows up in the browser's developer tools, so that's a little frustrating.

This probably is not the most satisfying fix to this issue, but now everything is working correctly. Hopefully this helps someone else. Thanks for all of the help! 👍

Q: What differences are between `format()` and `str()`? A:

I would like to add to Syntactical Remorse's excellent answer. I have been really enjoying using the __format__ method, and I believe I have a good use-case.

I may be a recent convert to python, but I found that I really like using __str__ and __format__ together to easily display custom formatted data or to default to a simple display to a user. In my CustomUser model I have the following code:

def __str__(self):
    '''What to print when printing a user's record.'''
    return f'{self.id} - {self.email}: {self.last_name}, {self.first_name}, deleted: {self.deleted}'

def __format__(self, print_format):
    '''selectively choose print format.  e.g. print(f"{user0:detail}") '''
    if print_format == "detail":
        fields = [field.name for field in self._meta.fields if field.name != 'password']
        ret_str = '\naccounts CustomUser record:'
        # loop through the fields (except password)
        for field in fields:
            val = getattr(self, field)

            if val == None:
                ret_str += f'\n  {field}: None'
            else:
                ret_str += f'\n  {field}: {getattr(self, field)}'
        return ret_str
    else:
        return str(self) # default to __str__ style print

when I code the simple statement print(f'user0: {user0}'), I get:

user0: CustomUser: 2 - gonzalezdavid@example.net: Molly, Barrett, deleted: None

when I simply add the :detail format print(f'user0: {user0:detail}'), then I get to see important debugging details such as fields from django-safedelete and django-auditlog:

user0: 
accounts CustomUser record:
  id: 2
  last_login: None
  is_superuser: False
  username: gonzalezdavid@example.net
  first_name: Barrett
  last_name: Molly
  email: gonzalezdavid@example.net
  is_staff: False
  is_active: True
  date_joined: 2025-12-13 01:10:30.911434+00:00
  deleted: None
  deleted_by_cascade: False
  created_at: 2025-12-13 01:10:30.911555+00:00
  updated_at: 2025-12-13 01:10:30.911557+00:00
  created_by: CustomUser: 1 - superuser1@sample.org: , , deleted: None
  updated_by: CustomUser: 1 - superuser1@sample.org: , , deleted: None

Q: Android Studio - Android Project View is Missing A:

I ran into this issue updating an Android Studio 2021 project to Android 2025 with Gradle 8.7 to 8.13. I had to sync to dependencies like another answer, but the configuration file was also somehow damaged.

From the menu bar:

  • Tools

  • SDK Manager

    • Build, Execution, Deployment

      • Build Tools

        • Gradle

          • Download external annotations for dependencies

  • Apply

Build assemble app configuration (Ctrl + F9)

This was the curve, usually the Android view shows up in the top two options, it was found on the bottom of the list. A surprising update.

After that I was able to add my assets folder in order to do a correct build of the project.
